channel.title: Net neutrality - at risk?
channel.description:
[b][u]Wireless carriers openly considering charging per service[/u][/b]
![](upload://8AjwqtOfYeUJpJHx5JZygMOmvTQ.jpeg)
That slide above is no joke -- it comes from a marketing webinar put on by two companies that count Verizon, AT&T and Vodafone as clients, and it describes a system that identifies customer internet activity and charges a different rate for using Facebook than watching YouTube, while allowing access to Vodafone services for free.
[url]https://www.engadget.com/2010/12/19/wireless-carriers-openly-considering-charging-per-service/[/url]

item.title: Net neutrality - at risk?
item.dc:creator: garrthbarrttinn
item.description:
sersoft:

Wow, if they adopt this strategy on hard lines I’m gonna have a laugh when my neighbors receive a huge-ass internet bill for unknown reasons.

Win.

On topic. Heard of this already and it is very bad. I’ll have to kiss my torrents goodbye. Oh, and ISPs will practically be able to choose what makes it on the internet and what doesn’t.

Read full topic

item.title: Net neutrality - at risk?
item.dc:creator: Wark
item.description:
On topic - I’m not surprised. This is what happens when you let oligopolies control all media in America. I’ve seen this coming for ages. I wrote my senator about the issue twice. It really doesn’t matter if the FCC doesn’t care and is being slipped money under the table.

They don’t and they are.

Here’s a little tidbit that shows the direness of the situation:

The ability by the FCC to regulate the Internet has been in doubt since APRIL, when an appeals court ruled The FCC lacked the authority to stop COMCAST from blocking bandwidth-hogging applications.

They can’t even protect your right to WATCH Netflix or download legal torrents. What makes you think they’ll be able to stop them from charging for them?

Read full topic
